title: Lesson 37 - More Uses for Sa, Adjective Phrases

vocabulary.english: for, at, on, in, to, etc.

contents.markdown: _Sa_ is a very versatile word in Tagalog. This lesson is to give you some practice with _sa_ by itself and as a compound preposition. Adjective phrases will also be covered.
Here are some uses you have already seen for _sa_ by itself. Notice how many English prepositions it is equivalent to.

item.tagalog: Tuturuan niya kami sa kuwarto namin.
item.english: She will teach us in our room.

item.tagalog: Nagbisikleta si Maria papunta sa eskwelahan.

contents.markdown: _Sa_ can be combined with certain nouns to make compound prepositions.
Ex: sa + loob (interior) = sa loob = inside
Ex: sa + ilalim (bottom) = sa ilalim = under
Ex: sa + labas (exterior) = sa labas = outside
These can also be used with nouns:
These can be used to answer _nasaan_ questions, so remember to use _nasa_ for the positive and wala for the negative:

item.tagalog: Wala siya sa ilalim ng bahay.
item.english: He is not below the house.

item.tagalog: Masaya ang babaeng kumakain sa tindahan.
item.english: The woman eating in the store is happy.

contents.markdown: As mentioned earlier, _babaeng kumakain sa tindahan_ is a noun phrase because, as a unit, it can replace a solitary noun. If you think about it, _kumakain sa tindahan_ is an adjective phrase because, as a unit, it can replace a solitary adjective:
Replacing adjective _masaya_ with adjective phrase _kumakain sa tindahan_:

item.english: woman who is eating in the store

contents.markdown: Noun Phrase + Linker + Adjective Phrase = Noun Phrase that/who Adjective Phrase
The reason we use “phrase” here rather than “clause” is that a verb is not required.

item.tagalog: Magluluto si Maria ng manok sa bahay ni Angel.
item.english: Maria will cook a chicken at Angel’s house. The sa phrase is applied to the verb, so she will actually do the cooking at Angel’s house.

item.tagalog: Magluluto si Maria ng manok na nasa bahay ni Angel.
item.english: Maria will cook a chicken that is at Angel’s house. The adjective phrase is applied to the preceding noun, so the chicken is one that is at Angel’s house.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Ayaw ni Jessica ang mga piso sa loob ng sapatos mo.
exampleSentences.english: Jessica does not want the pesos inside your shoes.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Hindi nila siya ibibili ng dalawang basketbol na nasa ilalim ng sasakyan.
exampleSentences.english: They will not buy her the two basketballs under the car.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Kailan niya itinanim ang puno sa labas?
exampleSentences.english: When did he plant the tree outside?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Opo, nandun ang pera, sa tabi ng ilaw na binuksan mo.
exampleSentences.english: Yes (resp.), the money is there, next to the light you turned on.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Gusto mo ba ang araw kapag nasa ibabaw ito ng inumin mo?
exampleSentences.english: Do you like the sun when it is above your drink?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Ituro natin sa kanila ang CR sa loob ng kuwarto nila.
exampleSentences.english: Let's show them the CR inside their room.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Kung ikukuha mo ako non sa ilalim ng bisikleta, igagawa kita ng pagkain.
exampleSentences.english: If you get me that under the bicycle, I will make you some food.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Nasa bahay ang anak ni Joe. Wala siya sa labas.
exampleSentences.english: Joe's son is at home. He is not outside.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Ihinahanap namin ng aso ang guro araw-araw sa tabi ng eskwelahan.
exampleSentences.english: We (excl.) search for a dog for the teacher every day next to the school.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Nasa puno sa ibabaw ng tindahan ang pusa.
exampleSentences.english: The cat is in the tree above the store.
